titleInfo.title: Memorandum in support of Senate Resolution 368

mods.abstract: Memorandum written for the Judiciary Committee in support of Senate Resolution 368, which would direct the Sergeant-at-Arms to arrest eleven witnesses upon whom the Special Committee to Investigate Organized Crime have been unable to serve subpenas. The memoranda presents legal arguments in favor of the resolution.

titleInfo.title: "Weekly Report from the Office of Estes Kefauver U.S. Senator from Tennessee"

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Senator Kefauver gives short remarks on Chinese Nationalists in the Korean War, modifying the draft to include men as young as 18, and the end of his own crime investigation.
mods.note: Senator Estes Kefauver's weekly reports were "made available to Tennessee newspapers and a 30-station radio network." In these reports the senator answered constituent questions and addressed controversial subjects.

mods.abstract: Estes Kefauver discusses his legislation banning interstate shipment of slot machines, the dangers of gambling, and the greatly underestimated role organized crime plays in the nation.
mods.note: Senator Estes Kefauver's weekly reports were "made available to Tennessee newspapers and a 30-station radio network." In these reports the senator answered constituent questions and addressed controversial subjects.

titleInfo.title: "Statement of Senator Kefauver When Introducing Crime Narcotics Bill"

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Statement of Senator Kefauver introducing to the Senate a bill requiring mandatory minimum penalties for violating narcotics laws (82 S. 1695).
mods.note: H.R. 3490, the similar bill before the House of Representatives that is mentioned in this statement, which changed the penalties for those who violated certain narcotics laws, was signed into law by President Harry Truman on November 2, 1951.

mods.abstract: Press release announcing that Senator Kefauver will not continue as chairman or member of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, and briefly listing the reasons why. titleInfo.title: Press release announcing introduction of three bills on juvenile delinquency in Washington D.C.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Press release on three bills related to juvenile delinquency in Washington D.C. The bills would allow police to confiscate equipment used in pornography; providing for a referee to hear juvenile cases; and clarifying status of Director of Social Work, respectively.
